content: 11 Soldiers Fired In Jan. For Being Gay U.S. Army Discharges Soldiers For Violating "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" Policy (CBS/AP) The U.S. Army fired 11 soldiers in January for violating the military's policy that gay service members must keep their sexuality hidden, according to a congressman. Democratic Rep. Jim Moran said he has requested monthly updates from the Pentagon on the impact of the policy until it is repealed. In a statement released on Thursday, Moran said the discharged soldiers included an intelligence collector, a military police officer, four infantry personnel, a health care specialist, a motor-transport operator and a water-treatment specialist. "How many more good soldiers are we willing to lose due to a bad policy that makes us less safe and secure?" asked Moran, a member of the House panel that oversees military spending. For Being Gay U.S. Army Discharges Soldiers For Violating "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" Policy (CBS/AP) The U.S. Army fired 11 soldiers in January for violating the military's policy that gay service members must keep their sexuality hidden, according to a congressman. Democratic Rep. Jim Moran said he has requested monthly updates from the Pentagon on the impact of the policy until it is repealed. In a statement released on Thursday, Moran said the discharged soldiers included an intelligence collector, a military police officer, four infantry personnel, a health care specialist, a motor-transport operator and a water-treatment specialist. "How many more good soldiers are we willing to lose due to a bad policy that makes us less safe and secure?" asked Moran, a member of the House panel that oversees military spending. If 'adverse consequences arise' I am sure it will come from the less than discipline heterosexuals in the form of sexual harassment.... but even that will be little as many in today's military are living in the real world of change and progress in welcoming diversity as fellow full-rights and privileges citizens, even in the military. Those in the know doubt very much there will be more than a tiny ripple - if that - and life will go on. Certainly among the 300 or so active duty I have polled in my classes in the military, very few are apprehensive of allowing gays to serve without the DA/DT rule or believe any other rule need to applied. The military has plenty of rules and regulations to handily manage any type of problems that arise. Some excessive heterosexuals might get out, but then one could speculate just what it was they were committed to? Gangs and drugs pose more of a problem in the military today as does the continual rise of domestic abuse at the hands of heterosexuals. But, I am all for heterosexuals serving, too.
